results.title: Can it hold together?
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, Ronald Dick and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
To examine this question, the film brings into focus recent historic events as recorded by the motion picture camera. We see the Commonwealth members in the arena of world affairs frequently taking diverging views on international issues but able, through their very differences, to serve as channels of communication between countries outside the Commonwealth. Edgar McInnis analyses some paradoxical situations that have arisen during the course of the Cold War, in which differing views and opposing loyalties inside the Commonwealth have helped to offset an East-West split. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Anybody's problem
results.creator_credit: John Fletcher, Leon Clore and Basic Films
results.brief_description: In Britain, the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux give free and expert counsel on problems as different as an eviction threat, the making of a will, a broken marriage and a scooter accident. Shot in Stevenage New Town, the film also illustrates the pattern of life in this new community, one of several designed to ease the population pressure on London.

results.title: Can a parent be human?
results.brief_description: An open-ended film from the Searching Years series which provides role-playing situations concerning communication between parents and children. Compares ways in which parents frighten children with ways in which they make successful contact.

results.title: Camp schools
results.creator_credit: British Films and National Camps Corporation
results.brief_description: Deals with the work of the National Camps Corporation which provides school accommodation for children in need of open-air treatment. A visit is paid to a typical school to show the accommodation provided and the variety of activities undertaken.

results.title: The Camp
results.creator_credit: Georges Pessis, Stanley Wright and United Nations
results.brief_description: Commentary spoken by Ingrid Bergman. Tells of a woman and her family who have lived in a refugee camp for ten years. They have had to rely on other’s charity because they could not work, and must wait to start new lives while others leave. The film ends as a challenge - the refugee camps will be burned as empty buildings if nations can give their help.

results.title: Camouflage in nature by pattern matching
results.brief_description: Explains how many animals bear protective colour patterns which blend with their variegated surroundings, thus providing a measure of protection. The film illustrates how those animals most needing protection, because of age, sex, or lack of ability to defend themselves, generally have subdued colouring. In contrast other animals, of a more offensive nature, have bold markings and dazzling effects.

results.title: The Camera industry of Japan
results.brief_description: Japanese cameras are world famous and eagerly sought after in the western world today. This film visits the factories and shows the methods used in the construction of various types of cameras which are exported all over the world.

results.title: Camels and the Pitjantjara
results.creator_credit: Roger Sandall, Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Shows the daily life of nomadic Central Australians of the Pitjantjara tribe who have acquired camels, guns and other modern equipment. Shows the capture of a wild camel and travels in the MacDonnell Range; hunting rabbits and living off the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roger Sandall, Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
